• another christmas design
  • worked on improving my previous design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2260213) and decided to make the new version a separate thing

  • prints without support (base part may need some, depending on your printer)

This is a 3D model of Mecano's V2 Prusa Air.
It is designed in Alibre and released in its native format as well as STL and STEP formats.

Download and use as you desire. 
The main purpose is to provide a 3D model of the entire printer so that the full advantage of 3D modeling can be implemented. By having a model of the entire system; interferences, alterations, improvements, etc can much easier be fixed, implemented, analyzed, etc. It is certainly incomplete at this point and therefore a work in progress.
I make no claim to any of the essential IP in these models as they are all derived from previous work. However there has been a considerable effort involved in converting the SCAD models into Alibre models. Idealy there would be a lossless path to bring OpenSCAD files into software that is better at building 3D systems. One excellent choice would be FreeCAD. There does seem to be some efforts towards that end, but I have not been able to get them to work. So for now I am recreating the models in Alibre by measurement (of the STL), by studying the SCAD files, and by measurement of the DXF data for the AIRV2. The AIR V2 parts are extrusions of the DXF outlines imported into Alibre
I have implemented certain improvements where I think they are deserved in the printable plastic parts. Primarily in the X-ENDS. I have removed the idler bridge member in favor of buttresses, and used Alibre's powerful filleting capabilities to change sharp corners into smooth transitions for strength.
In general the printable parts are derived from PRUSAJR-PRUSARMENDEL-8DCC230 release. The xplatform (or carriage) is from thing 9869.

title: Anti Back-lash lead screw nut mount

description.text:
This is an anti back-lash nut mount for 2020 aluminium rail or wherever.

It requires two lead screw nuts and one spring.

In addition to that you will also need
2 x 25mm M5 Low profile screws
4X 10mm M3 Cap head screws
4X 30mm M3 Cap head screws
4X M3 Nylon insert hex lock nuts
1X 30mm PUSH SPRING 9,5mm inner diam. 11,5mm outer diam.

I have printed these mounts and use them on one of my printer designs.
The result is a tight nut, with no womble or play at all.
By far the best-tightest-most efficient lead screw nut mount for its money :)

Printer setup;
0.2 mm Layer Height or lower
0,4 mm Wall thickness (or one layer depending on your nozzle)
80% Infill or more
20-50mm/sec max. Speed

ENJOY!

description.text: This is a remix of Skalla_J's spool storage system. I planned to build a tall one that could be heavy and wanted a robust handle. This lead to me redesigning the system to make a customer design with his STL parts as a starting point. The design was done in ANYSYS Spaceclaim Engineer. It is designed to stack as many spools as you want with the right length threaded rods and enough connector parts. I call it the Bumblebee spool storage system based on the colors I decided to use.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium or fast

Infill:

3 shells, 15%

Notes:

11-9-17 I removed the original drawer file and added a new one with a bump on one edge to keep the doors from swinging open.

Remove the support material, drill your holes in the spools and assemble. You may want to add some glue or lock-tight to hold the nut in place and lock the rod into the nut.

Either buy the right length threaded rod (unlikely) or trip it to length with a hack saw, Dremel, or other metal cutting device.

Used original design's stl files as basis and created new parts in Spaceclaim

Since I was going to make mine tall and potentially heavy, I decided to use a 1/4 inch threaded rod up the center to connect everything and provide addition strength to my redesigned handle. I went way from the T design of the original and closed the sides and added a center support that the rod goes through.

Heavy duty threaded rod reinforced handle. Cross section showing components Use temporary guides (red) to evenly align feet and hold in position while glue cures.

Drilling top and bottom holes.

I used a drill press but a handheld drill will work.

Step one, use top hole drilling jig for top holes.
Use one of the existing holes on the edge of the spool to set up location of hole 2 using the printable jig. There are two holes in the edge of the spool, use either one.

Carefully and slowly drill through the opening in the drilling jig. Rotate jig and drill holes 3 and 4

Rotate the jig 90 degrees and insert its post into hole 2, now drill hole 3. Rotate and repeat.

The existing holes on the bottom 90 degrees off from the top.

You can flip the spool over and use the same jig. However, since there are two holes you have to make sure to choose a hole that will align the new hole with the one on the other side. If you choose the wrong starting hole, just redo it with the right hole.

If your bottom holes are not aligned or 90 degrees off from top holes

If the holes on the other side of your spool are not aligned with or in 90 degree increments from the top you should use the alternate bottom hole jig to drill holes that are aligned with the top.

Alternate bottom hole jig Jig with guide screw installed in top. Drilling

Note the orientation of the jig. The thin end is meant to go on the side that has existing holes, the thick edge is meant to help you drill straight by providing more guidance.

If you are using a drill press or want to do this on a flat surface, print three of these to make the reel flat and stable.

Insert a screw through an existing hole and the jig. turn the jig and reel over, add the two other jigs for stability. Placement does not need to be exact, you just want them spaced like a tripod.

Use the hole that is on the other end of the jig to act as your guide for drilling,.

Non printed mods and assembly steps AND untested alternate drawer

Instead of using the small threaded rods as hinge pins for the drawers, I ended up using some lengths of 3mm ABS filament that I fastened in place on the top and bottom by melting them to the spool with a soldering iron. Works great. This is not my idea

The reason I did this was that my drilled holes weren't done as carefully as they should have been and alignment through the entire stack would have been an issue.

The second thing I did was add a little blob of melted plastic to the inside corner that is away from the hinge. I used my trusty 3Doodler for this job. Just melted a little blob of plastic, flattened it some with a finger press and closed the door while still warm. This adds enough friction so the drawers do not swing open freely. I could have added a bump to the design but then every drawer would have need to print with a couple of mm of support underneath adding time to the prints.

Another alternative would be to add a ridge on top of the drawers to make them tighter on top. I am loading that as the file named Alternate Drawer. It has not been tested yet.

Alternate drawer (untested) with raised lip

title: External battery holder for Casio fx-8000G and fx-8500G

description.text:
History:

A recent nostalgia crisis made me take my old Casio fx-8500G calculator out again. When A was a student, I modify it's power supply system because it was needing three CR2032 cells that was expensive and having a low capacity (to much black pixels on the screen was sufficient to drain them out of power) by a classical and inexpensive 9V battery (aka 6LR61).

The trouble with this solution is that the new cell was hanged outside the calculator by the wires that connect it to the calculator. Quite uncomfortable! So the idea to make a back-pack for my calculator to hold the battery.

Caution and notes:

Take great care of the polarity, a wrong connection can make you destroy your calculator!

To ease to battery removal I strongly recommend to add at least a piece of paper (pink on the photography) in the holder behind the battery. Ideally you can solder a ribbon to the holder.

When in position on the back of the calculator, this holder prevent the use of FA-80 interface. To use it, you'll need to unplug the battery, remove the holder and re-plug the battery without fixing the holder on the back of the calculator.

V2 on 2017/21/11:

Improvements :

  • refined shape,
  • pen holder for Bic Cristal (a cheap and reliable pen),
  • a holder for the connector's cover, hidden because the interface FA-80 is not usable with the battery holder fixed on the calculator.

Possible improvement:

  • adding a cap,

By the way!

It seem that enthusiasts conceive serial adaptor for the proprietary port on the left of the calculator. I'm not skilled about electronics and haven't the tools to make it but I can make enclosure....

Links:

  • http://www.pisi.com.pl/piotr433/fx8000se.htm
  • http://blog.damnsoft.org/rs232-ttl-adapter-for-vintage-fx-casio-calculators/ (note that if the connector is physically the same, their wirings are différent... too bad !)

Dreammaker overlord pro

description.text:
Truss bridge for the OS-Railway system. It's not modeled after any particular full scale bridge, only a composition inspired by many pictures on google. The OS-Railway system is a project with the aim of creating a fully 3D-printable and functional toy/model railway system in O-scale (1:45) which means 32mm track width.
If you drop by this page and haven't seen any of this before, check out the other related designs here: https://www.thingiverse.com/Depronized/designs

IMPORTANT! You can use the slope found on the arc bridge page, these bridges have the same height: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172709

Building is pretty straight forward even though it's time consuming, it's a big print!
NOTE! All STL's starting with Buildplate are the ones you should use, the other ones are only included to let you print spare parts. Prototype is 100% PLA.

  1. Print the "Build plate accessories" first, in that way you can start assembling when you get the sides ready. This plate need support! The orientation of the parts is important, it's done in a way so that the layer strength is in the right direction! I know it's tempting to rotate the "lower end connectors" to allow them to be printed without support, but if you do so you will put the layer weakness right where the part needs its strength the most.

  2. Print 2pcs of each STL called "Buildplate_Side_XXX". I suggest 0,2mm layer height.

  3. Print the STL called "Buildplate_track_2pcs", (or the one inly called track if you need to arrange it different, it's the same part printed 2 times and turned 180deg). I printed the prototype with the Prusa profile "FAST" with 0,35mm layer height and it actually works, but I would recommend 0,2mm if you have time.

  4. Print the STL called "Buildplate_tower_2pcs". NOTE! the towers are hollow, and you can stop the print at any desired height if you want a lower bridge. Standard height of the towers are 130mm (translates to 140mm to track base, same as my Arc Bridge). You an use 0,35mm layer height to speed this one up, it gives OK result, at least on the Prusa i3 MK2.

  5. Insert the parts called "Connectors" in the outer sides and glue the inner sides in place. This will lock the connectors in place. (CA, Superglue, Cyanoacrylate works very well).
    The connectors has been designed with a large play/tolerance, this is because the printing process will leave lots of material inside the holes where the connectors are supposed to slide in, and in my prototype which had much tighter fit, this ended up damaging many of the parts. Better have lots of play and use melt glue or epoxy, than having such a tight fit that the parts crack when assembling. It is especially important to check the bond in the middle, where the two mirrored sections join, although the track is held together you should make sure you have a nice glue bond here especially if you run heavy trains on the bridge.

Although there are screw holes for most parts, it's not really needed, you can glue most parts instead.

There are 2 ways of mounting the bridge to the towers, either use the two M3 screw holes in the middle, and place it edge-to-edge. Or you can put it only half way in over the tower, in that way you can build a two-section bridge using only 3 towers. A small connecting piece of track will be added. If you against all odds manage to build two sections before I publish the track joiner, let me know in the comments! :)

title: FT-817 Anderson PowerPole Adapter Power Connector

description.text:
This is the Original design for the FT-817 PowerPole Adapter that is available pre-manufactured on eBay at: http://stores.ebay.com/N0WL-Radio. I am posting it here for non-commercial use only.

Bill of Materials
• 3D Printed Shell
• Philmore TC240B Barrel Plug with 6’ Cable
• 15A PowerPole Adapter (30A adapters will work too)
• M3x12 Screw

Tools
• Wire Cutters
• Razor knife
• PowerPole Crimper (or soldering iron if you must
• Volt-ohm meter

Assembly Instructions

  1. Trim power wires to length
    a. Black wire: 41mm (1 5/8”) from strain relief
    b. Black & white wire (this is positive): 34mm (1 5/16”) from strain relief
  2. Carefully remove the last section of the strain relief. This is ~3mm (1/8”). You need to do this because of the tight clearance between the power socket and the radios feet. Use a razor knife to trim away enough of the strain relief to fit in the 3D printed shell. BE CAREFUL NOT TO CUT INTO THE INSULATION OF THE WIRE LEADS!
  3. Trim ~6mm (1/4”) insulation from the end of each lead. Twist bare copper wires to keep them from fraying
  4. Insert wire leads into PowerPole contacts and crimp. Or solder if you must.
  5. Assemble the black and red PowerPole shells together. MAKE SURE THAT YOU HAVE THEM ORIENTED CORRECTLY AND TEST AGAINST A KNOWN GOOD POWERPOLE CABLE. YOU WILL DESTROY YOUR RADIO OF YOU DO THIS STEP INCORRECTLY!
  6. Insert the black lead into the black PowerPole shell making sure you have a solid connection.
  7. Insert the black and white lead into the red PowerPole shell making sure you have a solid connection.
  8. Inspect your work. Use a volt-ohm meter to make sure that the center of the barrel connector is positive and the outside shell is negative.
  9. Insert the wire/PowerPole assembly into the shell. The red PowerPole lays on the edge farthest away from the barrel plug and closest to the ground post.
  10. Guide the wires around the shelf twisting counter-clockwise so that the barrel plug fits in the shell.
  11. Place assembly on the radio. Barrel plug in the power socket and fitted snuggly over the ground post.
  12. Secure assembly to the ground post with M3x12 screw.
  13. Optionally, use the screw to attach a ground wire.

Torpedo Lamp 2

With this Vase, Lampshade or object,
I tried to incorporate female and male forms in the torpedo concept.
I like this one very much :-)

The small one is printed in “smokey transparent PET-G”, 0.2mm resolution,

The big one is printed in “green transparent PET-G”,
0.35mm resolution, 0.5mm nozzle also in “spiral vase mode”
on my BIG DIY 3D Printer flow-rate 49% .
The green Lamp is 510mm high and that print took 19 hours. :-)

PS: I may have stretched these objects in the slicer program

description.text: These are printed slides for the mini Kossel printer. The original idea came from Bill Plemmons (http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/9940136066/). The scad file uses the fillets openscad library (https://github.com/StephS/i2_xends/blob/master/inc/fillets.scad). I am using them without the nylon screws, but the holes are there for it.

I printed these on a mini Kossel and you need a printer that is well-tuned to print these. As such, the tolerances are very tight. I use a length of extrusion to manually "burn-in" a newly printed slider. the friction softens the plastic a bit and smooths the feel. I then use a gcode program to "burn-in" the slider starting at 50mm/s and working up to 400mm/s. I have to run the printer as a Cartesian to get these speeds. I don't use the 3mm nylon screws Bill uses. I found they add squeak. I have run these at over 600mm/s (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DABFczCJ2QI). Time will tell if these are viable, but my accelerated testing says they will be.

As far as printing, yes I have my printer dialed in pretty well so I set the extra to 0. I would recommend downloading the scad file and adding some extra (it's a parameter int he scad file) and then printing test pieces only 10mm high to get a feel for too tight, just right, and too loose.

comments.text: I rounded the edges to save my hands from the sharp corners. I use a manual method to wear in the parts before I install them. I started with a simple chamfer, but the fillet looks better IMO.
comments.author: RickM

comments.text:
Jay,
I'm curious about your manual method to wear these in? I printed some 2020 sliders and found them to be quite tight on the extrusion requiring hammering with wood to get them on. Repeated on/off hammering onto/off-of the extrusion eventually resulted in a nice slip fit with zero slop fore/aft (carriage mount being front) and a very small amount of slop side to side. Are the holes in the sides meant to be for preloading the sliders to eliminate slop? I notiec the design makes use of groove rails on the inside that interface with the slot on the extrusion and that there are two to aide in constraining the fore/aft movement and only one (on the backside) to constrain the side-to-side movement.
comments.author: Jaydmdigital

comments.text:
The original design was a OpenSCAD version of one found on the net. The original designer was using these to hold nylon screws as the bearing surface. I found I preferred the PLA to be the wear surface and so I kept the tolerances very close. Depending on your printer it may be a nice slip fit off the printer. I left the holes in case wear was excessive and required some form of adjustment...but it hasn't been an issue to be honest.
I left one groove open to allow routing the wires, but it's a simple matter to have all 4 or to move where the open slot is. They may not even be needed since the wear is not that great (at least for the extrusions I have) YMMV.
comments.author: Apru

comments.text: Belt hole? No, you need to attach a carriage to the front of this to hold the belt still. It just replaces the MGN12 rail and truck.
comments.author: grb352

comments.text: oh yeah I meant the..looks at video again...I have no idea, I can't tell from attached test video what the hole is for then. the part has two holes (besides screw holes) a big one to ride the extrusion. and the other smaller one between the extrusion hole, and the carriage mounts on the front.
comments.author: Jaydmdigital

comments.text: The square hole is for the extrusion, the other is to save plastic. If you wanted it solid it would change the design, just comment that line out.

description.text:
Origami or artistic paper folding is an engaging math-art activity. There are so many ideas one can learn in an origami task, from words, shapes, spatial thinking, symmetry, fractions, to proportionality. However, most origami projects do not lend themselves to 3D design or printing.

The German Bell is one of the few that I have tried to make a 3D-designed model of. It works very well with PLA or flexible filament. Once the template is printed, removed with a spatula, please GENTLY fold the square along all the grooves, trying not to fold them completely, though. Once the creases are flexible, squeeze the four corners and allow them to come together SLOWLY. Meanwhile, push the bottom out a little bit. There you go -- a German Bell. It is an entry-level 3D design project as a complement to the traditional paper model.

The thicker versions may work better, depending on the filament.

4th Axis Tangential cutter for MPCNC

IN DEVELOPMENT

Designs and software likely to undergo updates. Please check back.

Recent updates

25/11:

  • Published update to gcodetools: manual path selection. Gcode cut order will match path selection order. See github link and manual_path_selection branch. Will merge once I've implemented optionality.
    • Printed out geodave's blade holder, and very happy with it. See below.

Older:

  • Moved gcodetools to Github.
  • Shifted to degrees for the turn magnitude, firmware changes required
  • Added support for full command by command speed control in the generated gcode
  • Switched away from the pineapple, and adopted a metal 5mm to 8mm coupler
  • No more thread moving inside the skate bearings - fashioned a smooth rod threaded at one end and clamped straight into the thread coupler - no top bolt, spring tension controlled by adding or removing washers. Not a critical update, more to follow.

See below for details

Further planned changes

Redesign blade holder - this one is too far from the tool mount. I will probably do something like the TOCK, where Olfa blade snap offs are used. Hopefully the rigidity of the cutting head can be improved.

^ Scratch this. Geodave did it better than I could have https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2661474

Inter-changeable pen mount - some cut out jobs benefit from markings, like using Fusion 360 Slicer.

Instructable detailing workflow for going from Fusion 360 Slicer output to useable gcode.

Intro

Like a drag knife, only able to cut more intricate designs and sharp corners. Also more suitable for thicker material. May be adapted for other tools which require 4th axis (A axis) rotation, and also for other CNC machines.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UMdeTK2p5F0
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cap5BHarNFA

Latest vid, working quite well now for thick (7mm) cardboard:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=2&v=Y-hkMQuFu2w

Hardware

Design changes incorporated:

  • Stepper motor to rotate the blade
  • Rotating assembly free to slide on two steel rods mounted to the MPCNC via linear bearings - allows rotation without losing the spring loaded z
  • Offset of blade tip to centre axis reduced to 0mm

In addition to the printed parts, you will need:

  • 2 x 608ZZ skate bearings
  • 2 x LMK10UU linear bearing
  • 2 x 10mm x 120mm steel or aluminium rods
  • 1 x Nema 17 stepper motor
  • 4 x M3 x 8 screws
  • 3 x M4 x 20 screws with nut
  • 2 x M3 x 15 screws with nut
  • 1 x M8 x 70 screw with lock nut, or M8 threaded rod cut to length
  • 15mm x 20mm spring (took mine from a £1 caulk gun)
  • 1 x standard utility knife blade

Optional:

5mm to 8mm metal shaft coupler (to replace pineapple, £1.50 each in UK)

Gcode Generation

A modified version of Gcodetools is supplied. Please note, this is no longer included in the Thingiverse page, but instead should be obtained from Github:

https://github.com/jamesd256/gcodetools

Three new parameters are introduced:

  • knife lift threshold angle (only lift the knife if the material thickness/angle requires it)
  • 4th axis command (allows generation of gcode with A commands substituted with E, see firmware below)
  • turn feed: Adds an FXXX gcode command to the turns, so turn speed is controllable.

Firmware

A small modification is required for best results with the standard MPCNC supplied Marlin firmware. In the first release, the code was outputting the turn command magnitude in radians. This works better with degrees, so the instructions now reflect that.

Marlin discards anything beyond 2 decimal places for E commands, which is why the change is needed. This means that with the magitudes associated with degrees, the firmware's over extrusion detection kicks in. Hence you will need to upload a new firmware to your Arduino, with the following two lines commened from configuration.h:

#define PREVENT_LENGTHY_EXTRUDE

#define EXTRUDE_MAXLENGTH 200

The stepper motor attaches to the E0 controller on the RAMPS board. You may need an additional stepper driver if you don't have one.

The generated gcode will have the 4th axis turns expressed in positive or negative degrees. The E0 steps per mm value needs to be set so that a value of 360 in the gcode corresponds to one full turn. In my case this was 103.xx steps per mm.

You can calculate the correct value by issuing a g1 e3600 command (10 full turns) and checking that 10 turns happen and the final angle matches the initial angle. If it's a bit slow add an F3000 or so to that command.

The latest gcodetools is modified to support feedrate gcode for individual turn commands which speeds things up.

See thread here:

https://www.vicious1.com/forum/topic/tangential-cutter-in-development/

And a precursor to the thread (motivation):

https://www.vicious1.com/forum/topic/drag-knife-not-making-sharp-corners/

Additional parameters and operation for attached Gcodetools

  • Follow instructions in README.md to install

  • Set the tool to be tangential knife:

    Extensions -> Gcodetools dev -> Tools library-dev -> tangient knife -> Apply

    • A green box will pop up. Use the Inkscape text tool to adjust the values:
      • lift knife at corner: set to how much lift you want in addition to current cut depth
      • 4th axis command: override to E ( from A) for MPCNC Marlin
      • Knife lift threshold angle: set the turn angle in degrees above which turns will have a lift. Eg: 45
      • Depth step: this is the maximum depth per cut

  • Create orientation points (this is where you'll control cutting depth or material thickness):

    Extensions -> Gcodetools dev -> Orientation points-dev -> Z-depth -> Apply

  • Generate the gcode

    Extensions -> Gcodetools dev -> Path to Gcode-dev

    • Preferences: set the directory to something other than the default /home/, then Apply
    • Options: set minimum arc radius to 10 (radians), meaning no arc commands will be generated (g2,g3) only straight moves (g0,g1). Apply (firmware struggles with arcs apparently - will test this soon)
    • Path to Gcode tab: Apply (make sure the vector you want to cut is selected first)
      • This will generate a new set of vectors in the drawing overlayed onto your cut vectors indicating the gcode commands generated
      • According to what you set for your output in preferences, this is where the gcode will be generated.
      • If your MPCNC Marlin is set right for E0 steps per mm, you can run the gcode directly.

Thanks to all over at the Vicious1 forums, especially Alted

Alted I borrowed your pineapple. Hope that's ok

comments.text: Thanks for the reply. I have one more question. Have you tried cutting foam board with it? I am wondering if it can be used to cut Flite Test plans on a DTFB?
comments.author: jamesd256

comments.text: Yes I have cut foam board very well.  However, because of the blade angle, the cut extends further on the top surface.  Therefore, if you cut shapes with acute angles, there will be some 'overcut' present.
comments.author: yuhahaha

comments.text:
I was wondering if X-acto blade would yield a better result for this purpose.
The needle cutter is definitely an interesting option, and generating the gcode for it is easier. The problem with needle cutter is the excessive vibration and noise.
comments.author: jamesd256

comments.text: The steeper blade angle reduces overcut, but calls for more rigidity as the shallow angle has more cutting power.  Hopefully I'll find time to finish trialling the new head and there can be a big update to the project.  Other stuff has changed in what I'm working with now to improve rigidity.  Now I'm using a smooth 8mm rod and linear bearings for the A/E axis, and is way less sloppy.  There are more details in the MPCNC forum thread.

title: Snapfit LED holder for Creality CR-10

description.text:
Simple snapfit LED holder for the creality CR-10. Intended for use on the top bar, but it does work on the vertical ones. It has a convenient hole and holder for the wires.

I do not recommend using high-powered LEDs as this model does not feature any cooling whatsoever.

Made to fit a common Chinese LED panel (40mm x 35mm)
Snap fit inner width is 6mm and 9mm outer (modeled for stock CR-10 profiles)

The print quality on my pictures is quite poor, that is mostly due to poorly set printing settings and has little to do with the model.

DIMENSIONS (everything in millimeter)
WHOLE MODEL: 50 x 40 x 32
MODEL WITHOUT SNAPFIT: 50 x 45 x 7
MAX LED SIZE: 40 x 35 x 5 (taller will fit but will stick out of the model)

Made using SolidWorks 2016

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm or higher

Infill:

20% with minimum area at 0.12mm

Notes:

Using a fine resolution (0.2mm or 0.1mm) is highly recommended because the model features small parts which do not print well at low (0.4mm) resolutions.

If you are using the model with text on top, set your "minimum infill area" to 0.12mm^2

You'll also need to rotate it in your slicing software, as the export tool set it on its side for some reason.

This is a case I designed for the Udoo X86. It's made to allow space for 1 SATA hard drive, position the antennas either on the top or side, and give access to the side ports + GPIO pins.

It's a very functional case, albeit not the slimmest, but it will protect the PC. There are mount points on the bottom to allow wood screws to wall mount the Udoo.

The orientation of the STL files are not correct, edit for best printing.

To assemble the case you will need:

4 x M3 20mm F-F Standoffs:

https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Female-Threaded-Standoff-Pillar/dp/B015A3LIXE/ref=sr_ph_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1509749214&sr=sr-1&keywords=m3+20mm

4 x M3 40mm M-F Standoffs:

https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-Female-Thread-Stand-off-Spacers/dp/B00AO432J8/ref=sr_1_7?ie=UTF8&qid=1509749231&sr=8-7&keywords=m3+40mm+standoff

8 x M3 12mm screws:

https://www.amazon.com/uxcell-M3x12mm-Carbon-Countersunk-Socket/dp/B01E6EIC2S/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1509749307&sr=8-5&keywords=m3+12mm+countersunk

The SATA hard drive should be able to press-fit into the slot its designated for. For the Udoo Antennas, use only the gold hex nut on the exterior of the 3D printed case (the lock nut washer takes too much thickness). I also had to hot glue the WIFI leads to the PCB to prevent them from detaching while assembling the antennas.

I provided the original Solidworks files. Feel free to edit.

description.text:
OpenSCAD version of justice777 clock case.
Added recess to fit the clock and have only 1mm thick front panel so that the LEDs can be seen better.
Added 4
Printed one copy, works OK with my clock, although the bottom screw stands are a bit off (by ~1.5 mm), but the 2 top ones are enough to screw-in the board.
If you need the 4 screws, modify the code a bit, basically I used 66mm for the horizontal distance between screwholes, but the vertical distance is more like 67 mm, maybe both are 67 mm after all. See back view picture (printed at 66mm)

Prusa Clone

Notes:

No specific issue for printing.
The stands holes are tight and slightly conical inwards, so you may need to drill or use a metal M3 screw to force the hole before using nylon screw.

Got justice777 STL files imported into Sketchup, ran Clean tool to simplify geometries, then used Sketchup measurement tool to get dimensions.
Rebuilt OpenSCAD code with dimensions as variables to generate identical STL.
Added recessed clock cavity, and then stands to screw-on.

description.text:
I designed a mount to attach a flashlight to my bicycle/ski helmet.

Fits 20mm diameter flashlight, I bought a 5 pack of them from Amazon for 15 bucks: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01D8DRFFI

There is a mounting piece that you stick to your helmet using double sided tape. The mounting piece has a 320mm diameter spherical curve cut into it so it matches up with an average helmet surface curvature.

You'll need two 2mm x 6mm screws to assemble. As you tighten the mount around the light, it also tightens into the dovetail mount attached to helmet. Loosen screws to remove from helmet.

description.text:
To celebrate my fiance's 30th birthday (the biggest Harry Potter fan I know) I decided to make this replica of the Hogwarts Express sign first seen in Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. After looking at countless pictures online and some other fan-made creations I settled on this design.

The biggest worry I had making the sign was painting on the lettering without making it look like a 5-year-old did it. I soon realized I could print the lettering instead :) This tutorial goes through the steps I took to create the sign. The STL files are the letters and 9 3/4 symbol, ready to print based on the size of my sign.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The STL files include the letters for each word, "HOGWARTS" and "EXPRESS". These fit on my Wanhao Duplicator bed (8" x 8"). Be sure to scale the text accordingly if it's larger or smaller than mine. There are modeling programs online (SketchUp, 123D) that can break the letters apart in case you need to print them individually.

The name of the font is Perpetua Titling MT, which you can download for free online.

Materials
  • (1) 32" x 11" x 1/2" piece of plywood. These dimensions end up working really well with the size and spacing of the letters. I ended up using a shelf board, which can be purchased at most home improvement stores. The dimensions of the board are very close to what I need
  • (4) 1/2" x 4'L square wooden dowels, long enough to cover the perimeter of the sign on both sides. You may decide you only want your lettering on one side of the sign, in which case you'll only need (2)
  • (2) 1/2" x 1/2" x 10'L Base Shoe Moulding. Can also be found in many home improvement stores. This is the rounded portion that goes inside the 1/2" square dowel perimeter. Not absolutely necessary but gives the sign more dimension. Only (1) needed if doing one side of the sign
  • (2) Screw-eyes, which allow you to hang the sign off the bracket
  • (2) Hogwarts crest sticker, found on Amazon. Again, only need (1) if you're doing one side of the sign
  • (1) 36"L bracket to hang the sign from. I found mine on Amazon
  • Spray Paint (see additional details below)
  • Wood glue for attaching the dowels/moulding to the sign
  • Superglue for attaching the printed lettering to the sign
Tools
  • Miter Saw. This is probably the most important tool. The ends of the 1/2" dowels & 1/2" moulding are cut at a 45 degree angle. This is very difficult to do freehand and a Miter Saw (or hand saw and Miter box) are essential
  • Circular saw or table saw. For cutting the plywood to size
  • Clamps for securing the dowels & moulding in place while the glue dries
  • Drill. Two holes need to be drilled for the screweyes to go into
  • Sandpaper for preparing your surfaces for priming
  • Painter's Tape
Spray Paint
  • Krylon Fusion - Satin Color. This is the primary red color that goes on the majority of the sign, including the edges
  • Rustoleum Metallic - Gold Color. The letters and perimeter of the sign are painted with this color
  • Black acrylic paint. I painted the lettering on the 9 3/4 symbol with this. You can also print the symbol in two different colors (black & white), which would eliminate the need for this paint
  • Primer. Any primer will do, just make sure you're using it since it helps the paint adhere to the parts better

1. Cut your plywood. My sign is 32"L x 11"W. Your sign may be different dimensions. If you choose a different dimension just be sure to keep the same aspect ratio (length/width). In other words, scale the height and width by the same percentage. Later on when you print your letters you'll need to scale them by the same amount
  2. Cut your square dowels. The ends of the dowels should be mitered at 45 degrees so they match up at the corners. Prime and paint the dowels with the metallic gold spray paint (only paint the side that will be facing outward)
  3. Cut your moulding. The moulding goes inside your dowel perimeter, so the pieces will be approximately 1" shorter than the dowels. Miter the ends at 45 degrees just like the dowels
  4. Dry fit your pieces on the plywood to make sure everything lines up and looks good
  5. Glue your dowels and moulding to the perimeter of the plywood. I glued the dowels first, clamped them into place, and let it dry before gluing the moulding
  6. Painting time! Use painter's tape to cover the gold paint you already put on the dowels, then sand, prime, and paint the entire sign (including edges) red. I recommend two coats of paint
  7. Print your lettering. Use the STL files to print your lettering and 9 3/4 logo, preferably using white filament. The letters are sized for a 32" x 11" sign. If your sign is larger/smaller then you'll need to scale your letters accordingly. Optional: Print the 9 3/4 logo using white for the base layers, then pausing the print and using black for the numbers and outer circle
  8. Paint your lettering. Prime your letters & logo. Paint the letters metallic gold. You will need to paint the outer circle and numbers a black color using your acrylic paint and a paintbrush (you can see my sloppy work in one of the photos)
  9. Dry fit the letters & logo on the sign. The logo sits on the center of the sign. The letters are a little trickier. I used an extra piece of the 1/2" dowel as a guide. I placed the dowel along the bottom of the 1/2" moulding, then placed the letter above the dowel. This gave me a consistent 1/2" space from the bottom of the letters to the moulding
  10. Glue the letters & logo in place. I used superglue for each letter, and one at a time, glued them into place, using the extra dowel as my guide
  11. Locate the sticker. The sticker goes near the edge of the sign. It's not shown in the pictures but I have the sticker on the same location on both sides of the sign (opposite where the sign bracket is located). So when you look at it from one side the sticker is above the "HO" letters, and on the other side it's above the "ESS" letters
  12. Install the screweyes. I drilled two holes at the top of the sign, being careful the drill bit is vertical so you don't drill through the side of the sign. The holes are spaced the same as the hanging holes on the sign bracket
  13. Mount your bracket and hang it! You're done! Congrats!

description.text:
This is a simple closable business card holder. Holds many standard 3.5"x2" business cards. It can be closed up and put in your pocket and taken with you.

You will need to pass a piece of filament through the holes and then use heat or glue to stick it to either the base or lid, but not both. I recommend fixing it into the lid. The inside of the lid will need support.
This was my first project to learn to use FreeCAD. I wanted to try something outside my normal modeling experience. I may upload one later with smoothed edges instead of chamfers.

title: HC-SR04 mount for RC Speed Tank

description.text:
This is a mount designed to hold a HC-SR04 Ultrasonic rangefinding sensor to the front of Bryant87's RC Speed Tank: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2024364

I remixed using dstark125's housing to create a mount which will fit over the front bumper of the tank while still holding the sensor level with the floor. On the top then is a cable tidy. This is going to be used as part of a robotic project I'm trying to work on.

If I work on this anymore in the future, I may add a clamp or screw holes to hold the mount in place on the bumper but for now it works well enough.

title: PE3D Ghettoblaster, Boombox, Bluetoothspeaker, Radio, Musik, DIY

description.text:
Since I want to give my nephew something very special for Christmas, I thought he could use a "mini ghetto blaster".
Because there was nothing similar to Thinkiverse, I sat down and pieced myself together.

Meanwhile I have several versions of it here. You can just puzzling those who like you better.

Version 1 is with built-in battery pack 12V li-ion
Version 2 is for AA batteries.

Current status of the project is: waiting for ordered parts

Parts list for the PE3D mini ghettoblaster.

for printing:

Maincase 5-15% Infill / 0.2mm Layer - OK
Front 15% infill / 0.1 - 0.15mm layer + Support 5% - OK
Backcover 5% - 15% Infill / 0.2mm Layer OK
Backcover for Batterie Version 20% /0.2mm + Support 10% - OK
Grid 1-3 100% Infill / 0.1mm Layer + Support 15% - OK
Grid v2 100% Infill / 0.1mm Layer - OK
Handle.stl 50% infill / 0.2mm layer - OK
Handle Beltholder 100% Infill 0.1mm Layer - OK
VolKnob.stl 80-100% infill / 0.2mm layer - OK

Speaker broadband 2x 50mm 10W 4ohm
https://goo.gl/PRKcwU
or
https://goo.gl/PYiFfh

On / Off switch 10pcs
https://goo.gl/htsDiu

Battery + power supply or Batteryholder
https://goo.gl/PhahMV
https://goo.gl/UDsV4C
or u can use 3x 18650 Li-ion Batteries because the ready set in the Link are cheaper.

Amplifier 2x10W PAM8610 Stereo Class D
https://goo.gl/sdbuZX

Antenna 25.4cm 5 sections
https://goo.gl/kbzG8J

Led version 3mm 10pcs
https://goo.gl/Thpe7u

Led 3mm 100pcs
https://goo.gl/mv6Sn1

DC plug installation 5.5-2.1mm 5pcs
https://goo.gl/PXB7NU

MP3 / Bluetooth / USB Player
https://goo.gl/6EQAGG
or
https://goo.gl/ZzjhQZ

additional is required:

-ca. 20cm 2x0,5mm cable for the speakers

  • acoustic wadding or similar to insulating the housing
    Screws metric 8x M3x10-25mm + nuts and washers (for mounting the speakers)
    -Screws Metric 5x M5x10-25mm for the lid
    -Screws for plastic joint countersunk 2x approx 3x10 (for the player) holes must be pre-drilled!

Plastic Adhesive (Uhu Allplast)
Soldering iron and solder
Shrink tubing or insulation tape

The project is still under development.
Pressure and assembly, only on receipt of the parts.
Then come real photos.

Have fun while rebuilding and listening to music
If you want to give me a donation for this work, I would be very happy about it.

10-11-17 Frontplate testprint was ok, but not perfekt, Corner adapted to improve haptics.

description.text:
Cup holder adapter.

Updated design v2

The interior tapers are now flat inside, and there's a notch out of the larger section to allow for large coffee mugs to also be used in the holder.

Initial design

Initial design is for the cup holder spot in a Honda CRV, which is not large enough to accommodate a Nalgene bottle. This adapter allows you to secure a Nalgene bottle in the cup holder location. I used some small round furniture pads to help secure the adapter in the vehicle location as well as a few inside the rim to hold the bottle a with a little more tension, but not so many that it gets stuck and pulls the whole assembly out when you pick it up.

May work on other vehicles, please report if it works in your vehicle to be added to the confirmed list.

Perfect Fit

2016 Honda CRV, driver's center console cup holder location using factory cup holder inserts.
2017 Subaru Outback

Fits but may be difficult to use

author: astroaaron

description.text:
I wanted a ring light for better facial lighting. Since I have a 3d printer I decided to make my own rather than buy one. Here it is:

Parts List:

  • 12v LED strip - http://a.co/fbHSTA4
  • 9v battery with connector
  • Switch - http://a.co/9NoQxi3
  • number 8 Screw w/ 2 nuts
  • Soldering equipment
  • Heat shrink tubing or Electrical tape
  • Super glue
  • 3D printed parts - https://cad.onshape.com/documents/b16b4bc1f1998f6d4070489c/w/dd39a70f7483493c4cf53a4d/e/e1741fed1e90d5fb6f279f53
    -Base
    -Lid
    -Ring
    -Knob
    -Lens - Clear

Steps:

  1. Feed the wires from the LEDs through the hole in the back of the Ring
  2. Peel the backing off the adhesive on the LEDs and stick them to the Ring
  3. Pinch and bend the lights at every corner
  4. Snap the Lens onto the Ring
  5. Thread one Nut all the way to the head of the Screw and super glue it there
  6. Fit the Screw into the Knob so the Nut locks into the hex shaped end
  7. Slide the other Nut into the slot in the Base
  8. Thread the screw through the Nut in the Base
  9. Slide the Ring into the slot in the Base
  10. Feed wires through the hole in the side of the Base
  11. Splice the black wire from the LEDs to the black wire from the battery connector
  12. Pop the Switch into the Base
  13. Solder the red wire from the LEDs to one pole of the switch
  14. Solder the red wire from the battery connector to the other pole of the switch
  15. Connect the battery and test the light
  16. Slide the Lid onto the Base
  17. Now take some awesome evenly lighted up close video!

remixed_from.title: Iron Man Mark III Life-size Helmet

description.text:
Since I have a large bed printer, I wanted to print as much as possible in a single piece to avoid issues I had previously with trying to glue parts together. This merge is NOT perfect but good enough for my kids costume. CHECK TO MAKE SURE THERE ARE NO GAPS IN YOUR SLICER.

Lots of supports are for the full helmet in once piece so recommend that you customize the supports to minimize print time on your printer. The inside does not have to perfect of course.

I have also uploaded a version with the top helmet and the base helmet separated. This would allow for far less support required for the overhang but will require manual gluing/welding the base and the top.

Print 2 copies of the ear disks. The bottom of the ear disks seem raised but I fixed by just adding a small -Z value in S3D so they are flat on the bottom.

Printer:

CR-10S4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Used 2 walls with 20% fill or less to reduce weight. Finished with filler primer and wet sanding before painting.
Face mask can be rotated vertically to limit tall supports however highly recommend you use a raft below the supports to increase stability.

description.text:
This is a quick design for a towel doorclip.
The clip slides over the top of the kitchendoor and can hold a towel.
It has "bulges" to hold the towel firmly.
Printed in ColorFABB PLA.

Printer:

Creality CR-10 / Hictop 3DP-20

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

200 µm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

50mm/sec (you can print faster if desired).

I created this using Autodesk Inventor. It fits my dresser that came with my apartment originally. It uses the long section on the top to create leverage and gives me a nice and out-of-the-way place to hang my keys. I have an aluminum climbing carabiner as my clip as well as ~7 keys, so my keychain is heavy, and this can still support it without bending or breaking.

If this doesn't fit your dresser, I'm sure you can easily customize one with a similar design. Also measure whatever kind of clip you use on your keys. Just get out your measuring tape and make a few adjustments to my design!

I printed this in 2 infills: 40% and 50%. The high infill makes it more sturdy. I printed it with 15% infill in a previous version, (PLA) and it snapped pretty easily. Also, in another previous version, it snapped due to being printed rotated 90 degrees about the Y axis. pretty much, the layers were perpendicular to the weight force of the keys, so this new orientation (on its side) is way better.
In summary, print with relatively high infill and in the orientation of the stl file (on its side). Also no supports (Yay!)

I printed this with Hathbox Gold PLA. If you are comfortable, I would suggest printing with a stronger polymer (ABS, PETG, wood, whatever). I print with just PLA now since I have a $200 printer.

author: cyberchucktx

title: Inventor Flashforge Dreamer metal hot end temperature 260 °C 280 °C

description.text:
Some 3D printer firmware (CTC, Flashforge Inventor, Creator, Dreamer) will limit extruder printing temperature to 248 °C.
How to deal with it?

Change firmware or change hardware!

To change firmware:

Backdated firmware "dreamer_2.4.20160603" will allow to print with upto 280 °C.

"For installing the “dreamer_2.4.20160603” firmware there are two options:

I. Temporarily downgrade Flashprint to 3.12. It has the option to install the 2.4.20160603 firmware. After the firmware installation you can upgrade Flashprint back to the most current revision.
II. Remove the internal SD card from the Flashforge Dreamer. The bottom of the printer has to be removed for this option, which is quite easy to do. Place the micro SD card in your pc using an adapter and replace the existing dreamer.bin under the subdirectory “sys” with this version: dreamer.bin. Make sure to backup the existing dreamer.bin, so you can return to your previous firmware in case there are any issues."

  • the source of this idea and file came from http://uptimefab.com/2016/03/25/install-all-metal-hotend-flashforge-dreamer-print-test-pc-plus-polycarbonate/

To change hardware:

Install 33 ohm Resistor in parallel to Thermocouple.
The Flashforge printer use Type K Thermocouple - thermoelectric voltage as a function of
temperature. By adding 33 ohm resistor in parallel we trick system by -10 °C, so system will show 248 °C but in reality the temperature is 258 °C.
Use a little switch to turn it on/ off so you can check temperature while printing.

Both methods work, my preferences is to change hardware.
Now i can print:
PC Polycarbonate EXTRUDER TEMP 290±20 °C;
Nylon X Polyamide With Chopped Carbon Fiber EXTRUDER TEMP 260±10 °C;
ASA Acrylonitrile Styrene Acrylate EXTRUDER TEMP 250±10 °C

description.text:
This is my first "thing" uploaded here. It's a replacement clip for a foldable camping table. The table is comprised of a number of aluminium slats held together by elastic, which folds up concertina-style and fits in the carry bag along with the tubular legs. The tabletop clips to two 19.5mm dia aluminium tubes via four of these clips. The tubes also connect the concertina legs assembly, once extended.
Being only lightly screwed on, one of the clips was lost. This clip is a 'good-enough' facsimile and works well. The clip is attached to the outer slat with two self-tapping machine screws, the sort recovered from scrapping an old printer or other piece of e-waste.

The design for this was originally done as a profile in QuickCAD then exported as a DXF to SolveSpace for some more mucking about then from there imported into OpenSCAD where the clip profile was extruded and the holes and locating pin added.

I printed a prototype in natural PLA, made a slight adjustment to the mounting holes distance then ran off the finished one in black PLA. It has enough flexibility for the aluminium tube to snap in nicely and is quite strong enough for this purpose.

UPDATE: I have added the profile DXF and OpenSCAD script so you can adjust it to suit your own circumstances if you like.

This cyberpunk inspired accessory works perfect with an Adafruit 60m NeoPixel medium density strip. Two varieties: small spikes and a lavish crystal-inspired variation where each spike is a different shape and size giving the strip variation. The spikes are hollowed making cavities that allow them to fully illuminate. Designed for printing with NinjaFlex filament.

Check out our full tutorial with circuit diagram Print with NinjaFlex filament @225 with non-heated build plate. Mount a 60m NeoPixel strip with Permatex 66B silicone adhesive. Wedge some magnets into the sheathing of the neopixel strip with the magnets wrapped in tape to prevent shorting any connections underneath the strip. Match up the magnets so that the strip is held from inside your garment.

The normal markets for earphone-to-collar clips are full of clunky, multi-part clips that get in the way of running. The designs of these pins are less obstructive and can be used to wrap up the earphones after you are done. You can use a Form 2 printer with a photo curable polymer to print out multiple pins in the same build. The CAD file has one side that is flat for the purpose of orientation.

Photos with bright and wonderful star light are always considered as amazing master piece. Only using a very simple star filter can realize this goal. The Star filters can create wonderful dazzling star effects from original point light sources or bright reflections. But all the filters we can see in the online market just have very simple geometry and can’t have a perfect performance when they are made with traditional plastic molding. In contrast to these, we designed a 3-D printed multi-layer star filter which can have multiple different more complex star light effects. You can customize your own pattern of the filter and you can even combine several filters to make a very complex star light effect.

title: GepRC MX3 Sparrow VTX Antenna Holder

description.text:
I found that when using a 20mm Flight Stack with a UFL Antenna in the GepRC MX3 Sparrow frame that it tended to come straight out the back right in line with the props and it would hit them occasionally. So I drew this Antenna holder up in Fusion 360 to plug into the existing carbon fibre antenna mount and accept a 2mm antenna cable to bend it up out of the way.

Should also work with any standard SMA/RP-SMA hole in 1.5mm carbon plate. It slips over the antenna cabler and clips snuggly into the carbon plate. Should be short enough to accept clover leaf and dipole UFL connector antennas.

description.text:
Update: Turns out, these are actually a smidgen too long. If you put 2 of them on top of a 40 footer, it hangs over. So, in your slicer, reduce the length of the side walls, roof and floor by 3mm, and your good to go. :)

Your support can help me to create and release new designs.
Become a Patron!
Thank you.

This is, in my opinion, a better 20ft shipping container. Why better? 1. The dimensions are correct to scale (not all the current offerings are) 2. It has the correct number of ribs 3. It has forklift lifting points (i've not seen a 3d printed one yet that does) 4. The details are clearer.
In order to achieve good detail, I designed the container in parts, so assembly is required. Also uploaded a 40ft, 45ft and 53ft version.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Notes:

Speed 40mm/s

I recommend assembling in the following order:

  1. Glue 1 side to the doors, aligning the hinges.
  2. glue the floor, aligning the bottom of the floor with the top of the forklift lifting holes
  3. Glue the roof in place, with the top edge of the ribs flush with the side
  4. Glue the end wall in place
  5. Finally glue 2nd side.

title: iFlight R1 X5 Rear VTX Antenna Mount

description.text:
VTX Antenna mount to suit iFlight R1 X5 frame.
Just slides over the standoffs and accepts SMA/RPSMA bulkhead mount from Immersion RC, Team Black Sheep, Matek and similar VTX's.

Printed this one in PLA and it has stood up to a few crashes where the antenna got bent well out of shape, so should be good to print up in just about any material you have on hand.

Allowed space to run the power cables out the rear of the quadcopter under the antenna mount.

It will work fine in other frames with 30mm tall standoffs and 21mm spacing between centres of the rear standoffs.

title: Wanhao i3 Plus Z axis stabilizer (Cocoon Create Touch)

description.text:
Z screw stabilizer for Wanhao i3 Plus

To install,

  1. Undo the plastic clips in the gantry which holds the ribbon cable

  2. Undo and remove all screws securing the top part of the gantry

  3. Lift up the gantry

  4. Slide the stabilizers on, flip one of them upside down for the right Z screw

  5. Gently pull the screw and rod away from the gantry, match the 2 circle nubs on the gantry to the notches on the stabilizers

  6. Reinstall the gantry

  7. (Optional) Use 4x longer M3 screws (10 or 15mm) to thread into the stabilizers

description.text: My wife got a new bag with a strap that was too long. You can scale it to the width and thickness you need (though it may "thicken" the tab that hooks behind the strap). If you need to further modify, I've uploaded the .blend file - the geometry is really simple. description.text:
I wanted to create a poseable action figure that was easy and reliable to print.

I also wanted it to be easy for others to remix and add to. Feel free to add whatever you want to him. I'll certainly add some armaments at some point.

The parts are all press fit beveled octagonal pegs and circular holes, making for a surprisingly firm fit. The holes are 10mm in diameter, as are the pegs (between opposing vertices).

The pegs are tough to get into the holes by design. I used a hammer to assemble mine.

Jimbo ends up about 7in tall.

Chest x1
Hips x1
Head x1

Foot x2
Hand x2

Shoulder/Hip Cap x4
Limb Panel (Pegs) x4

Limb Panel (Holes) x8

All parts print without supports except the chest and hips.

Please post pics if you print and/or remix it!

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I have an XYZ printer so I don't know how thick the walls are, but it probably doesn't matter too much.

About

This is a customizable parametric processor delidding tool. Variables can be edited to fit any LGA (Land Grid Array) processors. PGA (Pin Grid Array) processors do not work with this tool.

Go to the Imgur album to see all of the pictures.

Note: For some reason, the previews for the tool base part aren't rendering properly. That is not how it will look when you print it. To see an accurate representation, look at the first screenshot of the OpenSCAD window, or the second render of the example STL file.

Customizing

You must customize this tool for your processor. The default settings are for an LGA1366 processor, which probably isn't what you're using.

Open the Customizer app, and change the variables to your processor's measurements. You probably don't need to change any in the box-margins tab.

If you are confused about any of the parameters, all you need to do is ask for clarification.

Note: When measuring the CPU, enter a little extra room, about ±0.2mm on the width and depth, if your prints shrink. If you have great dimensional accuracy you probably shouldn't worry.

Instructions

  1. Lay the processor inside of the tool base as you would for a motherboard socket.
  2. Place the tool cover over the top of the processor so the ridge underneath butts against the edge of the processor's IHS.
    • The underside of the cover (facing up when printed) should be flush against the top of the processor.
    • There should be a gap between the inner edge of the tool base and cover the same length as the margin (default: 5) specified in the variables.
    • The top side of the cover and base should be flush with each other.
  3. Use a C-clamp or equivalent to press the base and cover together.
    • The threaded side of the clamp should be pushing down on the top of the cover.
    • The non-mobile part of the clamp should be on the bottom of the base.
    • Tighten the clamp securely, don't be afraid to put pressure on the processor. If there isn't enough pressure, the cover may slip and break during the next step.
  4. Place the tool in a vice, lengthwise. This will put pressure on the side of the PCB and IHS to separate the silicon seal between the two.
    • The C-clamp will be perpendicular to the force of the vice.
  5. Slowly close the vice until you feel or hear the silicon seal break. There should be an audible snap, and tension on the vice will be reduced suddenly. The gap between the two parts should also be gone.
    • You may want to hold the middle of the clamp while closing the vice, as when the seal snaps it may fall out of the vice.
  6. Take the tool out of the vice, and carefully remove the clamp.
    • Hold the cover and base together while the clamp is removed.
  7. Take the processor out carefully, preferably dump it in your hand upside-down. The IHS and PCB are now separate, and your warranty void.

You should know what to do after opening the processor. The rest is on you.

Disclaimer

Your warranty is now void.

This is a risky process, but potentially very beneficial. Your processor may break. If you don't know what delidding is, please research the topic thoroughly before proceeding.

You can delid processors without a lip on the IHS, just set lip_depth to 0. However, only do so for Intel processors. Do not delid AMD processors! All AMD chips are soldered with indium, so there is no reason to delid them anyways. See this video by der8aur if you want to know more.

I am not liable for any damage caused by this tool.

remixed_from.author: SirJon
remixed_from.title: FT-817 Anderson PowerPole Adapter Power Connector

title: Yaesu FT-817 Anderson Power Pole Adapter (ND version as well)

description.text:
I made a new design that is shorter so you have easier access to the power poles and better visibility for alignment. I am including the STL file with the name "short" in it.

Thanks.

=================

I printed mine with Support for the bottom inset Screw to secure the adapter to the radio. You may not need to.

Tight fit, but works. Once installed you won't need to worry about it again. I bought the updated longer screw at Ace Hardware. The size that works was M3 - .50 x10. It cost $0.27. CHEAP! I used standard set of PowePoles and soldered the connectors. Be real careful when cutting for length on the PowerPoles. You get one shot! The power cable was the standard Yaesu Power Cable. My wire with the white stripe was positive. Check yours for accuracy for + and -. It's a tight fit so I placed the cable on the corner piece and then pushed the big piece in second. That works great. Easy to assemble and then forget about the cable. You probably use a fuse system of sort. That's your call. Good luck with this.

Total price list:

Yaesu Power Cable: FREE (Came with your radio)
Filament Cost of material: $0.14
Anderson PowerPoles : $1.00 (roughly the cost for a pair)
Screw: $0.27

Total: $1.41

There is a seller on ebay that sells this pre-assembler for people who do not have soldering capabilities or a 3D printer. LOL.

http://stores.ebay.com/N0WL-Radio

The ebay seller goes under the name of: wayward_child

Original design and creation was from the following individual:
Jon Poland, N0WL aka wayward_child

Thanks for looking.

K0ESX

Damon Downing

description.text:
Always mixing up your charged and discharged batteries at the field? Cover your charged batteries with these connector covers for easy identification!

Gone are the days of sifting through a pile of batteries searching for a charged pack. Pop a cover over your charged batteries before heading to the field and remove before flight. Charged batteries are covered, discharged batteries are un-covered.

Simple, so you can stay organized and focused on flying.
To use:
• Place a cover over your charged battery's XT-60.
• Remove at the field when ready to fly.
• Covered packs are full, uncovered packs are empty!
• Printed for snug fit. Secure halfway for easy removal.

Want more information? Check out our article on Propwashed:

https://www.propwashed.com/store/xt60-covers/

Notes:

Print with the bottom of the cover facing the print bed. This will allow the best quality print.

Created from the standard wooden artist dummy, this model was created with the intention of having a 3D 6ft figure that I could use in my modeling for reference.  
Please note that this model is not designed to be printed with moving parts, and has not been optimized for printing without supports due to the numerous over hangs.  
This model is scaled 1 inch = 1 foot (scale your print as required)  
This *.STL file has not been posed, provided with a base, optimized for support or posts as the intention, as noted, is to provide a jointed model to custom pose as required.  
Please use this model as you would like and keep me updated on progress.
Modeled originally in Rhinocerous.  Pose your character and manipulate the file to reduce overhangs while printing components.

remixed_from.author: ChrisParish
remixed_from.title: CR-10 E3D Titan Direct Drive Extruder Mount for V6 and Volcano

title: CR-10 E3D Titan Direct Drive Extruder Mount for Volcano Hotend

description.text:
Volcano_CarriageMount-_Body_V2.stl: increased the difference from 8.7mm to 10mm, added parameter in CAD version for easier change.

I wanted to convert my CR-10 to Direct Drive Extruder with Volcano Hotend.
My first approach was using the Volcano Direct Mount (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2214530) from jailcee, but the part cooling fan holder was constantly dropping into my printed part, thus ruining the print.
My second approach was using the respective mount from ChrisParish, but this mount was build for the standard E3Dv6 hotend.
Thus I remixed the part, added additional 8.7mm total height (difference between both hotends) and stretched the part cooling fan by 5.7mm height.
The source of the remixed part can be found here: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/974f2bec4d5b1de6f266b46d/w/cbbde19acf498d51eea57275/e/fb6c535081caae678ab6ce58
Stretching of the fan was done with NetFabb.

comments.text:
May you, please, add a new mount body which supports 18mm probe and bltouch ?
Thank you
comments.author: tsmaa

comments.text:
Great work! It hadn't occurred to me that the exit of the fan duct would be at the wrong height. I have now added a fan duct to the original design with the exit 8.5mm lower.
If you haven't moved the whole thing up and you are using an end stop to set the height above the bed then don't forget to replace the stock one with an adjustable one or you will crash the head into the bed!
comments.author: ChrisParish

comments.text:
Yeah - I just noticed that the 8.7mm seem to be not enough difference, since I have added some glass bed holder additions to my CR-10 which reduce the play of the springs below the bed. Additionally I've changed my Z-endstop to a variable one, since I had printed it already and I thought it would be faster compared to printing my V2 mount.
I had to differentiate the positioning of fan duct and extruder since moving the fan duct also by 9-x mm would result in having the screws which clamp the mount to the x carriage directly in the middle of the horizontal plane and thus negatively impacting the stability of the mount. Thus the bottom part (where the fan duct is attached to) was only lifted by 5.7mm, the upper part (where the extruder assemply is attached) can be varied as wanted (in V1 set to 8.7mm, in V2 set to 10mm).
comments.author: ChrisParish

author: mightynozzle

description.text:
Ryan's Wooden dinosaur.

Would ja bat over that?

Maybe.

Pop a cork in it, and set it alight - hollowprint.

Print these parts:

  • Scale_Holder
  • Clamp_Jaw

There are two clamp bars one has a hole at the end the other has a hole in the middle. Use the one you prefer.

  • Clamp_Bar // Hole at the end
  • Clamp_Bar_P // Hole in the middle

These parts are small and will require rafts:

  • Pointer

  • Clamp_Wedges

    Print Angle-Throw-Gauge.pdf.

    Assembly

  • From Angle-Throw-Gauge.pdf cut out a scale.
  • Use 3M 77 Spray Adhesive or similair, to fasten the printed scale to the scale holder.

Assemble the clamp:

  • Put a wedge through the hole in the Clamp Jaw
  • Push the clamp bar through the hole in the Clamp Jaw
  • Slide the wedge and check that the clamp jaw is locked
  • Four wedges are printed. Use the one that works best

    Pendulum and Axle

  • Bend a paper clip to make the pendulm and axle.
  • Push the Clamp Bar into the square hole on the Scale Holder.
  • Align the hole in the Clamp Bar with the hole in the Scale Holder. A paper clip through the hole will help alignment.
  • Glue the clamp bar in place.
  • Push the pendulm axle through the hole in the Scale Holder and Clamp Bar.
  • Push a small peice of tubing over the axle. It will stop the pointer from rubbing on the scale.
  • Push the pointer on to the axle. A drop of glue will hold it in place.
  • The pendulm should move freely without sticking. Use solder to increase the pendulm weight.

Sources

The clamp is a remix of “Hobby Clamps” by ModelStation, Hobby Clamps

And uses The Angle-Throw-Gauge.pdf, by Dennis Summer, Dennis Sumner's blog

Edit

2017/11/5 add new photograph and construction sequence
Designed using OpenScad.

description.text:
I often carry my soundcore and phone around together so that I can stream content to the speaker. This little caddy makes it easier to do.

The soundcore slots into the front part of the caddy, and there's a slot behind it that can take my phone, even when in a protective sleeve.

I've kept it relatively thin and light, it's meant only for carrying room to room, so could be made stronger if required.

I had a printing problem when making this that caused a misalignment when printing which can be seen in the photo, but that isn't in the model itself.

Just added V2 which is 1mm narrower and has smooth sides

A8

Yes

50%

Notes:

I printed this on it's back (handle horizontal) with supports. Removing them from the phone slot with thin pliers. I printed with 1.2mm walls and 50% infill to ensure the handle was strong enough which it seems to be.

title: RamjetX Logitech G25/G27/G29 70mm Hub Adaptor Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi Internet Sim Racers!

I present the Logitech 70mm Hub Adaptor "kit" with 2 versions and a Quick Release Hub Adaptor.

Whats in the Pack?

1) Standard 70mm adapter puck similar to that which is very popular.
2) Stubby 70mm adapter which replaces the whole hub assembly and shifter paddles that allow you to reduce the shaft length.
3) The RXM 70mm Quick Release adaptor with matching profile for the Stubby and Thrustmaster hub adapter profile.

I'm finalizing some magnetic shifters for simhub compatible wheel plates and will release them to match all hub profiles too.

Check out the pictures... Its pretty straight forward. All screw lengths are a standard store bought sizes...

Print with 30% in fill... 2mm walls and top/bottom... make it strong, print it about 40mm/s for layer strength and final surface finish. If you can go faster, go for it. My prints come out amazing at these settings.

If you've downloaded it... I'd love to get a like, and if you've printed one, I'd love more to see pictures of your setup :)

comments.text: i just made an account to say that this is an awesome design! i was impressed with how well the "stubby" fit into the G920.  Great job and thank you for making it available , cheers mate! ill post a photo when i get a solid print
comments.author: drift1

comments.text: Hi drift1,
comments.author: drift1

comments.text: Is this a complete set to mount a custom wheel to my g29? Or do I need to buy some other adapter to fit your adapters to be able to mount the wheel.
comments.author: Mike2560

comments.text: It's a complete kit. It has the basic puck adaptor for fitting on top of your stock shifter paddles. It has the stubby adaptor which removes the shifter paddles if your using a wheel plate with it's own shifters. It also has the quick release adaptor if you want to fit one of those as seen in the pictures too.
comments.author: Mike2560

comments.text: Is the stubby hub for removing the buttons? As in either mounting an aftermarket quick release or straight to the wheel with no buttons/paddles?
comments.author: Polr

comments.text: Yeah that's right. You can see how long the shafts can get with some quick release kits. Typically when modding an aftermarket wheel, people tend to put their own wheel plate and shifter kit on it. The stubby mount shortens the length and keeps it 'reasonable' without looking too long. You'll see some people have put their own wheels on but their adaptor only matches the stock hub which means your stuck with the original shifter paddles.
comments.author: Polr

comments.text: I also have 2 more questions. Im going to use a 3d printing service to print this. https://www.3dhubs.com/3dprint what would you recommend pla or abs and what should the layer height be? Thanks.
comments.author: RamjetX

comments.text: hey mate which material did you end up using? the ABS or PLA?
comments.author: Polr

comments.text: Since your not taking the time to print it... I'd recommend 0.2mm layer height. 2mm walls/top/bottom as a minimum. Slow print speed gives best layer adhesion, and 30-50% infill for sheer strength.
comments.author: Polr

comments.text: how to print this flat?
comments.author: mty02b

comments.text: Just rotate the model 90 degrees in your slicer.

author: Cyborgdaron

title: Bottom mounted spool holder for 2040 aluminium extrusions

description.text:
Remixed this stylish spool holder by PhantomGT.

I needed to mount my spool holder on the bottom of a 2040 rail, and since the original requires no screws and is held in place by gravity, I had to reverse the direction of the mounts and rotate the top part of the spindle by 180 degrees.

Have lengthened the arm slightly, added some lightening holes as well as trimming the base section - to help reduce filament used and printing times.

Also if you're running dual extruders like me, you can print a mirrored model and join them together with a M4 bolt - I've added a screw hole in the middle of the arm.

title: Y Axis Plates - Flying Bear Tornado

description.text:
The Y axis plates on my Flyingbear Tornado were not flat and this was causing the linear sliders to bind and not work smoothly. These plates were designed to replace the bent metal plates.

I have not had them installed for long, but they make a huge difference in operation.

Since they may be exposed to the heat from the bed, you may want to consider PETG or ABS.

Also, if you want drawings or files for the original metal plates, send me a note.

print_settings.Notes:: The inserts can be printed very hollow, but I suggest printing the actual holder at 100% infill. This way you do not ever have to worry about printing it again. These are very sturdy and can handle multiple filament rolls at the same time. However, since they are tall, if you swing your arm and hit them head on, they may not survive. :p

title: Hictop Perfect Spool Holder Prusa I3

description.text:
This is a direct replacement for the top of the acrylic hictop printer. 3dp-03 and several similar models like the 3dp-08 among others.

It utilizes an 8mm shaft with 608zz bearings glued on both ends. I actually did notice an improvement in print quality after installation. There is next to no force required by the extruder to pull filament due to the bearings and inserts. The 2 inserts fit most standard filament rolls. The inserts have lips to keep your rolls from coming off. It just works, and looks nice. Happy Printing! :)

Needed
8mm shaft (could be printed, I suggest layed flat for strength, but a steel rod is best.)
2x 608zz bearings
glue

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

No

No

.3

20-100%

Notes:

The inserts can be printed very hollow, but I suggest printing the actual holder at 100% infill. This way you do not ever have to worry about printing it again. These are very sturdy and can handle multiple filament rolls at the same time. However, since they are tall, if you swing your arm and hit them head on, they may not survive. :p

author: Skitrak

title: Bahtinov mask for Vixen Ark 80mm binocular

description.text:
The Bahtinov focusing mask is remixed for Vixen (Giant) Ark *x80 binocular. Internal diameter of the ring is 94 mm. It perfectly fits on the rubber hood of each binocular side. Can be used with
Vixen (Giant) Ark 12x80
Vixen (Giant) Ark 16x80
Vixen (Giant) Ark 20x80
Vixen (Giant) Ark 30x80
Vixen (Giant) Ark 16-40x80

PS: I'm not sure if it works properly since Focal length divided by mask step should be inside [150,200] or [50,66]. While this mask has 4mm step and unclear F of binocular. I can only suggest that F=300mm for these binoculars, since it looks natural for the binocular size.
PPS: Test has shown that it works nice with point sources of light (with stars shall work as well) even with this mask params.
Relationship of 75 if considered good (inside [75,100]) according to the source as second order spot use for optimal focusing.
http://www.astronomy.ru/forum/index.php/topic,10421.msg426807.html#msg426807 (in Russian, use translate.google.com if required)

Printer:

JGAURORA Z - 605S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer 0.2 mm Nozzle 0.4 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I tried to print it with PLA only. For ABS there may be contraction in size, so some additional scaling factor may be required.
Good heatbed leveling is a must to put initial layer with minimal adhesion errors. As practice have shown some minor errors in initial layer are not a problem for end result.
Brim should be used against edges warping.

This mask is scaled from the original mask.

scale([0.555,0.555,1.0])
